displayed_text:
[Question]

Do you support the government provide basic health insurance for everyone?

answer.text_box: I do not support basic health insurance for everyone. We see how the (un)affordable care act (0bamacare) has caused costs to skyrocket. We don't need insurance because of high health care costs; we have high health care costs because of insurance.

displayed_text:
Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Overall stance: The vast majority (well over 90%) support the government providing basic health insurance, with a small minority opposed.
  • Core reasons for support:
  • Moral and civic duty: Healthcare seen as a human right and part of government’s responsibility to ensure citizens’ safety, well-being, and dignity.
  • Access and affordability: Many cannot afford insurance under the current system; people shouldn’t die or go without care due to cost.
  • Efficiency and cost: Belief that universal/basic coverage would lower costs through risk pooling, reduce waste, and ultimately be cheaper for society. Some frame it as a competitiveness and national security issue.
  • Private market shortcomings: Concerns about for-profit insurers denying care and the market failing to deliver good outcomes despite high costs.
  • International comparisons: Other countries (e.g., Canada) provide universal care; respondents want the U.S. to follow suit, though with faster access and fewer delays.
  • Caveats and preferred designs:
  • Maintain choice: Support for a public option alongside private plans; some oppose making government coverage the only option.
  • Scope: Favor basic or essential coverage for all, with skepticism about expansive government-run systems and intrusive monitoring.
  • Performance expectations: Strong emphasis on timely access, efficiency, and avoiding long wait times.
  • Funding/eligibility nuances: A few mention taxpayers explicitly and/or universal opt-in to spread costs.
  • Minority opposition:
  • Concerns that government is inefficient and will reduce quality; belief that the private sector is better suited and that “nothing is free.”
  • Additional points:
  • Anticipated health benefits include earlier diagnosis (e.g., autoimmune conditions).
  • Frustration with current thresholds for programs like Medicaid and the perceived gap in coverage.

Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Overall stance: The vast majority (well over 90%) support the government providing basic health insurance, with a small minority opposed.
  • Core reasons for support:
  • Moral and civic duty: Healthcare seen as a human right and part of government’s responsibility to ensure citizens’ safety, well-being, and dignity.
  • Access and affordability: Many cannot afford insurance under the current system; people shouldn’t die or go without care due to cost.
  • Efficiency and cost: Belief that universal/basic coverage would lower costs through risk pooling, reduce waste, and ultimately be cheaper for society. Some frame it as a competitiveness and national security issue.
  • Private market shortcomings: Concerns about for-profit insurers denying care and the market failing to deliver good outcomes despite high costs.
  • International comparisons: Other countries (e.g., Canada) provide universal care; respondents want the U.S. to follow suit, though with faster access and fewer delays.
  • Caveats and preferred designs:
  • Maintain choice: Support for a public option alongside private plans; some oppose making government coverage the only option.
  • Scope: Favor basic or essential coverage for all, with skepticism about expansive government-run systems and intrusive monitoring.
  • Performance expectations: Strong emphasis on timely access, efficiency, and avoiding long wait times.

  • Frustration with current thresholds for programs like Medicaid and the perceived gap in coverage.

Summary B

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Broad consensus in favor: Over 90% support the government providing basic health insurance for everyone; a small minority opposes it.
  • Main reasons for support:
  • Healthcare framed as a human right and matter of fairness, independent of income, employment, or background.
  • Improved access and affordability: current costs are seen as prohibitive, leading to medical debt and delayed or forgone care.
  • Better outcomes and societal benefits: earlier diagnoses, healthier workforce, national security/economic competitiveness, and potential system-wide efficiencies via a universal risk pool.
  • Comparisons to other developed countries suggest it’s workable; some want a model “like Canada but faster.”
  • Skepticism of for-profit insurers’ incentives to deny care.
  • Conditional/nuanced support:
  • Preference by some for a public option alongside private plans to preserve choice; others favor universal participation for efficiency.
  • Emphasis on timely, quality care and streamlined administration.
  • Support focused on “basic” coverage; caution against extensive government control or intrusive monitoring.
  • Funding and fairness concerns appear in the form of ensuring taxpayers benefit.
  • Reasons for opposition:
  • Doubts about government efficiency and quality; preference for private-sector solutions and reducing dependence on government.
  • Additional themes:
  • Strong frustration with current costs and access; belief that no one should have to choose between necessities and medical care.
  • Calls to include essential services (some explicitly mention dental) and attention to vulnerable groups, including the unemployed and low-income individuals.
